item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Former C.E.O. Is Sentenced to 19 Years in Corruption Inquiry
item.description: Marcelo Odebrecht, the former chief executive of Brazil’s largest construction company, was convicted of corruption and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: Marcelo Odebrecht, former chief of a major Brazilian construction company, in July 2015. He was convicted of corruption and money-laundering on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Broadens Sanctions on Joseph Kony and His Group
item.description: The Treasury Department action against Mr. Kony and the Lord’s Resistance Army, an African guerrilla organization, could hamper their ability to raise money by selling poached ivory.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Obama Seeks to Pave Way to Mideast Deal After He Leaves Office
item.description: President Obama is looking past his time in office and weighing a plan that would preserve at least the principle of a two-state solution for his successor to pursue.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel last year.

item.title: Iranian Unit Tests Missiles, Accusing U.S. Of Threats
item.description: Accounts on state television did not specify whether the military had fired any weapons capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, which would violate a U.N. resolution.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: South Korea Accuses North of Hacking Senior Officials’ Phones
item.description: Seoul’s spy agency says that Pyongyang has stolen text messages, contact information and voice conversations, possibly in retaliation for new sanctions.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by North Korea’s official Korean Central News Agency, purportedly showing railway workers in West Pyongyang protesting last week against United Nations Security Council sanctions.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Authorities Take Over Another Opposition News Source
item.description: The Turkish authorities have seized control of the Cihan news agency, expanding the crackdown against supporters of the Muslim cleric Fethullah Gulen.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Government Raises Its Target for Admitting Political Refugees
item.description: The government said Tuesday that Canada would bring in a total of 55,800 political refugees this year, many of them fleeing the Syrian civil war.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Houthi Rebels Enter Peace Talks With Saudi Arabia
item.description: A delegation from the Houthi rebel movement is conducting peace talks directly with Saudi Arabia for the first time since Yemen’s civil war began nearly a year ago.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: W.H.O. Advises Pregnant Women to Avoid Areas Where Zika Is Spreading
item.description: The committee said that they were not recommending that pregnant women avoid whole countries, but that they avoid only “areas” where mosquitoes are transmitting the virus.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the W.H.O, and Dr. David L. Heymann at a news conference on Tuesday in Geneva after a meeting about the Zika virus.

item.title: American Graduate Student Killed in Stabbing Rampage Near Tel Aviv
item.description: Taylor Force, an Army combat veteran and Vanderbilt graduate student, was killed by a Palestinian man who attacked groups of people in Jaffa.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Eating Leaves, and Other Ways Besieged Syrians Try to Survive
item.description: The report detailed how civilians in 18 areas across the country are forced to scrounge to survive.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Trilobites: How to Watch the Total Solar Eclipse
item.description: Skywatchers across Southeast Asia and the western Pacific can witness a solar eclipse. Here’s how to observe it from other places, too.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR
item.media:description: Students and teachers in Indonesia test their protective glasses and look at the sun in preparation for Wednesday’s solar eclipse.

item.title: Deep Rifts Among Israeli Jews Are Found in Religion Survey
item.description: The Pew Research Center found that religious and social divisions in Israel are reflected in “starkly contrasting positions on many public policy questions.”
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Lod, Israel. A study found that only 1 percent of Israel’s Muslim, Christian and Druse minorities said they had a spouse of a different religion.

item.title: Q. and A.: How Europe’s Deal With Turkey Aims to Resolve the Migrant Crisis
item.description: A look at the tentative accord reached Tuesday to help address the migration crisis that has roiled the Continent.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE, MELISSA EDDY and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A makeshift camp near the Greek village of Idomeni on the border with Macedonia, where thousands of refugees and migrants are stranded.

item.title: Afghan Court Confirms Reduced Sentences in Mob Killing of Farkhunda
item.description: Men sentenced to death in the brutal killing of Farkhunda, a young woman who was an Islamic scholar, had their sentences cut to as little as 10 years.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Yaqoub, left, and Zainuddin, two of four men who were sentenced to death for the killing of a woman named Farkhunda, in prison in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October. All four sentences have been reduced to as little as 10 years in prison.

item.title: Pakistani Politician’s Son, Abducted 5 Years Ago, Is Found Alive
item.description: The Pakistani police and intelligence agencies found Shahbaz Ali Taseer, the son of a former governor who was assassinated eight months before the kidnapping.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Shahbaz Ali Taseer in 2011. The police and intelligence officers found him Tuesday in a compound in Baluchistan Province in southwestern Pakistan.

item.title: E.U. Woos Turkey for Refugee Help, Ignoring Rights Crackdown
item.description: To win help with the migrant crisis, Europe seems prepared to overlook what critics say is President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march toward authoritarianism.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Demonstrators were hit by tear gas in front of the offices of the Turkish daily newspaper Zaman in Istanbul on Saturday. The authorities raided the newspaper.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: As the Taliban Menace Afghanistan, the Helmand River Offers Solace
item.description: The resilience of Lashkar Gah, a city known as Little America, is reflected on the riverbank, a gathering place that has inspired at least one poem.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Helmand River valley of Afghanistan in 2010.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Cameron’s Moment of Truth
item.description: As Britain heads toward a crucial referendum on membership in the European Union, the prime minister is already losing allies.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: South China Sea Buildup Brings Beijing Closer to Realizing Control
item.description: The swift military expansion and island-building efforts have raised tensions while advancing China’s goal of a security buffer far from its coast.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The People’s Liberation Army Navy patrolling on Woody Island, in the Paracel chain, in January.
